title: Substitution Cipher
description:
Tutorial from @VideoGamerCanInvent: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/74567664/#editor 

Music is Ancient Hateno Tech Lab (Zelda Breath of the Wild) - KHInsider

Remix suggestions: change the cipher! Make the encryption more complicated! Add other kinds of functionality!
instructions: Simple substitution cipher; if you want to change the cipher, go to backgrounds and change the letter order around in the cipher list. Not super complicated, but fairly tedious...one cool thing I learned was how to make your sprites spell out the words they say, like they're being typed live! Simple, but I hadn't thought of it. :)

title: Mystery Word
description:
My initial concept for Day 14 was to write a program that detected whether two words rhyme. A bug in my code (that was scrambling my letters) led me to this project instead. A big thanks to @jsh who played numerous iterations of the game to help me test. Together we went from "This is the worst game ever. I want my money back." to "You've got some bad bugs." to "That's much less annoying." to "Good game! Major upgrade!" It's so helpful to have someone who is willing to be totally honest with you! :)

Music: https://archive.org/details/ReallyOldRecordingsSetA
instructions:
This is a two-player word game!
Player 1 enters a mystery word and three one-word clues to help Player 2 guess the mystery word.
The program scrambles the word, which Player 2 then needs to guess.

title: Truffle's Idea Tumbler
description:
updates on this iteration for Day 20:
I made a few detail edits, such as adding in spaces between the responses that Truffle joins as an idea. Sometimes when trying something new, the details are missed, and I'm glad to come back to this! I also added a feature where you can add a question to Truffle's memory. What question might bring some playful ideas?

original notes:
AHHHHH - This was my first time exploring strings and lists!
^---- that's a very excited ahhhh!

At first I wasn't even sure what the string blocks might be used for. I started off by looking at the Scratch wiki (https://en.scratch-wiki.info/wiki/String) to see what they even did. (thanks @paulinah)! Then I thought that I would create something that generated randomized text. 

The most exciting part of creating this came as I was thinking of questions to ask. As I plugged in Ask " " and wait, and "add answer to list" at least 15 times, and saw my code grow longer and longer, I wondered how I could randomize the questions so that they might appear in another order (or be repeated, for re-considering other potential responses.) I thought, if I could put them somewhere and ask for a random one, that would be great. I had just created my first list of the answers to questions. It was a sparkly realization moment when I thought "what if I stored the *questions* in a list, too??? This way, they could both be randomized when called upon and ALSO be more organized, not making my script forever long. I was honestly feeling kind of unsure about taking on lists -- and there I was, creating lists on lists to be joined in (lovingly) weird strings! I'm excited to see where this new discovery goes!

During the recent Getting Unstuck project on changing scenes, I decided to try a "pause and come back" strategy in stuck moments. When I paused, I'd go in the vector editor and work on this cat face, thinking I'd surely use it for something in the future. I felt comfortable enough to play around with creating the cat while also thinking through the challenges in the project I was programming. For this challenge, I didn't spend ANY time on drawing, as I'd already created the cat. I wonder how far I would've gotten in the lists + strings exploration if I were also focusing on creating my own graphics?
instructions:
After pressing the green flag, press the space bar to start.

Once Truffle has started sharing potential ideas, click on her and she'll share more (:

(update: press up arrow to add a question to Truffle's memory!)

title: Visual Editor
description: This project was created for Day 14 for Getting Unstuck. I wanted to explore the idea of drawing text and making a text input box, but without using Scratch's built-in "say" or prompt features. It was definitely a challenge, and I ran out of time before getting to many of the features that I would like to explore. So I plan to keep working on it in future, maybe as a remix for a future day of Getting Unstuck. Fun!

title: Bad Poetry Generator - Day 14 of Getting Unstuck
description:
credit to Freesound.org for the computer sound
Beat-nik by J.M. Van Eaton (Cool Daddy O 60's beatnik music)
Unsplash.com for the Cafe Background

This was fun. After looking at the first couple projects submitted I was paralyzed! They were so good! 
Then I realized I could counter that with something sooo baaadddd!
I have used operator blocks more and more during the last two weeks. However, I really have not used the list blocks before. I saw them in someone else's project, realized how it could be used, and tested them out. Much easier than I anticipated. That, added to the realization earlier that I could randomized broadcasts, didn't make this too hard in the end. Except making the poetry and trying to get Scratch's beret correctly drawn. 
Didn't know it was a beret? I'm not surprised!
instructions:
Click on the green flag and answer the questions. 
Be prepared for some questionable poetry!

I'm quite happy with this result. I'd like to have made the user's name appear with only a capital initial and the rest in lower case, but I'm not sure that that's possible. Likewise, I'm not sure if I can make sure that users put in an actual number (eg 4) rather than the word (four). Apart from that I'm quite happy with this. title: Getting Unstuck: Day 14 — Taco Cat
description:
Reflection

This was a fun little project to do and came together fairly quickly. Once done, and after initially posting, I went back and refactored the code, which is probably where I spent the majority of my time. I happen to like refactoring quite a bit as this is usually where I learn the most about programming. Highly recommend! :)

How it works: After the users answers Scratchy, the script processes it by pulling out only the letters of the alphabet while creating variables forward and reverse. This is to prevent spaces and specials characters (ie !@#$%) won't be used in the check. The letters in variables forward and reverse are then checked against one another. If any comparison isn't identical, then it isn't a palindrome.
instructions:
Tell Scratch Cat a word or phrase and they'll say if it's a palindrome or not.

For example, try "taco cat".

title: wAvInG LeTtErS
description:
Getting Unstuck - day 14
by Massimo Marletta

In this project I used some blocks regarding text (for example extracting a single char from a text, or calculating le length of text) together to the function of recursive cloning of sprites.

The letters are sprites with a costume for each character, the costume of each sprite is selected by analyzing the string. 

The wave effect is given by changing the size of the sprite according to a sinusoidal function with a time shift different for each letter.

In another project of mine I use the same logic to simulate a transversal mechanical wave: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/236681045/
instructions:
Input a text by clicking on the pencil and see it moving like a wave.

In another project of mine I use the same logic to simulate a transversal mechanical wave: 
https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/236681045/

title: Getting Unstuck 14
description:
I thought doing a hangman-style game would be fun, but I didn't know it would end up so complicated! 

My process was to build it step-by-step: first figure out how to choose a random word from a list and display it. Then figure out how to hide the letters and prompt the player to guess. Then figure out how to show the letter if they guess right and keep it hidden if they guess wrong, and so on. I tested it at each step to make sure it was working. I didn't always do the steps in an order that made sense - for example, I put in the rescue bird before nearly everything else because the idea popped into my head ad I thought it would be fun (and make the game have a happy ending!).

I didn't get stuck exactly, but I feel like there must be a more elegant way of doing it. There's a lot of repetitive code here.

Music is Water in the Creek by Josh Woodward via the Free Music Archive
instructions:
Click the green flag to start. Click each box to guess what letter it is. Try to spell out the word before the Scratch Cat sinks!

Hint (because the game is really hard otherwise): All the words are Scratch-themed.

-make it a 2-player game, where another player types in the secret word to use

description:
Getting Unstuck: Day 14

I got stuck in a deep rabbit hole, aiming for a fully ECMAScript compliant implementation. I used the "compromise" strategy to get unstuck: I reduced the scope to ship a working product :)
instructions:
This project contains a new scratch block that I have been missing:
a custom "substring" block that extracts the part of an input string between the given start and end indexes.

Feel free to use this in your projects without giving me any credit.
See inside for more details :)

title: Haiku vs Cut-Up 2 (Unstuck 14)
description:
This is the first time I've played with the string blocks, wihich is part of the reason why I love Getting Unstuck: it challenges me to go beyond what I usually do. 

This is a short experiment with the "cut-up" (or "decoupe") technique that I first encountered via William Burroughs' "Towers Open Fire." This projects takes a haiku by Kerouac and converts it to a randomized version.
instructions:
Version 2 Update:

Thanks @alirb for the suggestion of adding player input (and for nudging me just a bit further than I thought I could do!) 

I'm on a train right now and wifi is intermittent. This needs some polishing - specifically, I'm still trying to find a way to remove the randomly selected word from the list (so it doesn't repeat) unitl all the words are used. Any suggestions will be given finger snaps in appreciation.

title: Deriv14
description:
GettingUnstuck Day 14, a remix of ideas from several projects earlier in the GettingUnstuck series. Working alongside students today, I made a five note instrument out of toaster tongs and copper tape. See sprites for a photo of the instrument.

The idea of using mouse x and mouse y to change notes was an exciting discovery.

There is additional graphics code that had to be disassembled because they were causing the program to freeze.
instructions:
Green flag, draw with fingertip on track pad

Designed for makeymakey with grounded ring, connect to right left up down and space (see photos within). Change notes by changing mouse-x, change instruments by changing mouse-y.

to play theme from Close Encounters: left, up, right, space, down

I almost forgot the unstuck theme of wordplay! For wordplay, I used a koan I wrote for PZ's PoP. Each time a note is played, the number of letters in a random word from the koan are displayed.

title: Unstuck Day 14
description:
I must confess that I had very little time today and was rather overawed by some of the projects.  But, I have never used string blocks before so I decided to go simple which is all my frazzled brain can cope with today!  I was really pleased with the result.
I thought the children would love to do this as a simple project to get into using string blocks, they would be so excited to see their name appear!  I might use this as an intro activity, when we're back at school!

I struggled with removing the item from the original list so that it cannot be typed a second time.  Any help with this would be great.  I hope you enjoy playing the game.
Please let me know what you think of it (any constructive or helpful comments are very welcome!)

I made this game as my daughter loves word play apps. This could be easily changed by addition of lists.
Maybe there is a way of typing up a few lists and importing a list at the start of the game via a question.
I hope that I did this correctly to achieve the aim of the lesson.  Ive been trying to challenge myself but really not sure about the variables, making my own blocks and that matematical aspect. 
 Click the green flag - read what the lion says then try to guess the words.  If you get them correct you'll get a point and the word will appear in the results window.

title: Falling Letters!
description:
Phew! Speaking of getting unstuck, today I was stuck all the time! Scratch is lot of fun EXCEPT when you have to stick blocks into blocks into other blocks... I was also in a rush today, so my code is not very elegant. Translating letters into numbers and again in costumes was hard, and also the routine that checks if the user writes a number costed me a lot of time. Exhausting but rewarding.  

Fun thing: this is a remake of an example program of a dBase III tutorial. Nowadays almost no one even remembers dBase III, it was a powerful language mainly used to manage databases before SQL. MS Visual FoxPro was based on dBase III, but it was short lived.
instructions:
Guess the secret word! Select how may random letters you want to be thrown out from the plane, then use LEFT/RIGHT to get them.
If the letter is part of the secret word, then they will be revealed.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 14: Zodiac Finder
description:
I was inspired to make this project to teach people a little more about their zodiac signs! It was fun to figure out how to parse the letters and then set the month and date to align with the horoscopes. Originally, when I tried to do this, I got stuck because a month (for example, April) could mean one of two signs. I think I worked around this pretty well, but there's probably a more elegant execution of this.

If I had more time, I'd make sure there was a response for the user making a typo/not typing a correct birthday. Right now, it just stops :)

Zodiac descriptions based on this guide: https://www.allure.com/story/zodiac-sign-personality-traits-dates
instructions: Click on the green flag. Type your birthday with only lowercase letters when prompted (example: may 24), then learn about your zodiac sign!

title: Do the Jiggen! Getting Unstuck Day 14 Strings
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 14 Strings

So this challenge was super fun. Not that many hurdles to overcome, things pretty much worked the way that I expected them to.
I tried a new strategy: in the past, I would have likely broadcast two messages like "dance" and "nodancing" in order to coordinate all the different sprites' activities in the two situations. However, I tried using what is essentially a true/false variable and found that it worked rather well, as the sprites only do simple repetitive things in each different condition.
instructions: Click the different buttons on screen and see what happens!

Create a secret message using a cipher wheel.

title: Beatles: Love in 3 Words
description:
I got stuck several times dealing with all the lists in this project, but reviewed old projects and examples from other Scratchers to help sort it out. Using blocks with visible output like 'Say ()' is a go-to debugging strategy, as well.

Making this reminded me how complex even the simplest games are deceptively complex to create. It's an issue I think about all the time when creating game design activities for new coders!

With more time, I'd like to make the scripts for this project simpler to understand, so that it could be used as a demonstration of how to make a quiz like this one.

Music samples from Amazon

title: Getting Unstuck Day 14 Remix: Iglatinpay Amenay-4
description:
Loved the original! Here's another take on the idea . . . 
Took a while to figure out how to get the first letter moved to the end.
So happy when it worked, almost forgot to add "ay". Timing still not quite right and project seems to have gone from a few extraneous bowtie spins to not quite enough - will probably compare to previous drafts. Still thinking through the progression of steps when using the broadcast block, strings, loops and direction changes. 
Would not have considered remix before Day 11 challenge. Glad to have a model to work from, and not always having to start from "scratch".

title: Aliebn Lamguage
description:
The inspiration for this project came from one of the most wonderful and inspiring stories I've ever read, "badly spelled and beautifully written", in which a little alien lands on Earth to find out what is a human.

In the book, the alien speaks a very particular language full of misspellings and typos, that makes it super cute. So I tried to write a Scratch program to translate from human to alien language.

That turned out to be much harder than expected. I thought I could just replace letters but it turned out that it was much more complex because quite often the translation of a letter depends on the letter that is before and/or after, and there are a lot of exceptions. 

My unstuck strategy was to "keep it simple", so I made a couple of simple substitutions. Then I tried consider the previous letter and I made the simplest thing I could, which was "mispeling" double letter words. If I had more time I would dive deeper and try to implement the entire aliebn grammar.. for now I think it's cute enough! EDIT: I couldn't resist so I also made a simple filter that removes "I'm" or "I am" from the second answer.. it is not very robust, but it's good enough!

Here are more info about the book and the alien language:
https://www.pri.org/stories/2017-09-27/how-speak-aliebn-no-thats-not-typo

Hapy learming friemds!
instructions: Meet a little alien who's learning about humans.

title: Getting Unstuck 14
description:
After a 10 hour work day near New Hampshire, then a trip to Boston, didnt' think I'd get it done today. But I enjoy working with strings. 

I thought to slow it down so it was easier to follow what is happening but decided that fast is fun. You can also use the text engine to type sentences and has some roughly built in margins. Will need a few adjustments but the framework is there.
instructions:
Ok, got it done. 

Type a word, the index will go letter by letter to add it to a list in order. Then we'll randomize the index to add the letters to the scramble list and delete the list item from unscrambled.

Once all the letters are scrambled we will join them all back into the scrambled variable. Then we'll run that scramble variable through my text engine which will then clone the letters centered on the screen.

title: A Word With U
description:
I wanted to make a word-guessing game for Getting Unstuck day 14. The idea for the mechanics of this game came from a pun: "A word with U" could mean a word that starts with 'A' that also has a 'U'.

It was easier to find a word list than I thought it would be! I got it here: https://github.com/first20hours/google-10000-english/blob/master/google-10000-english-usa-no-swears.txt (You can upload a txt file to a list by right clicking on the list in the editor.)
instructions:
You have 60 seconds to guess as many words as you can! (This project only knows the most common 10,000 words in American English, so guess accordingly.) Proper nouns (like "California") and common acronyms (like "ISBN") are welcome!

If you can't think of a word, you can type "give up"-- but beware, you'll lose some points.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 14
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 14 Reflection:
I had no idea what string blocks were or how much fun they could be until this project.  And I had no idea what I wanted to try with them until I started looking at projects in the studio.  I was really impressed with CompTeacherK5's project and decided to try to make my own.  (Here is a link: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/237066028/#player).

I got stuck when I tried to link more than two things in a join block.  It took me a long time to figure out that I could nest them.  Something I'd like to change or enhance (besides the rather lame story I came up with!) is adding other effects to it, like sound effects.

description: When I was younger, I would always create stage names from online forms. I wanted to recreate the process using Scratch. I found this project relatively simple and know that I can expand the options to include inputs about immutable facts such as birthday and hair color.
instructions: Press the green button and wait to hear instructions from Roy!
